title: Starting My Python Journey - From Business Analyst to... We'll See Where This Goes
content:
This is it. My first real blog post about learning Python.

Starting my Python coding journey

I've been staring at this blank page for way too long, second-guessing whether I should even start this blog. My immediate reaction was dismissive: "Why should I do this? This is banal. Everybody has done this. This is just basic stuff for a lot of people." But then I did what any good analyst does - I looked at the numbers. ## The Numbers That Changed My Mind Here's what really put things into perspective for me: - The world population is about 8 billion people - Approximately 30 million people worldwide are software developers - Around 10 to 20 percent of these developers maintain blogs or create content So if you are a software developer creating a blog, you're already in a relatively small, engaged group: 30 million developers × 10% = 3 million content-creating developers globally Comparing that to the entire global population: 3 million content-creating developers ÷ 8 billion total people ≈ 0.0375% of the world's population **If you create and share your learning journey publicly, you join an exclusive community representing less than 0.04% of all people worldwide.** Suddenly, my "banal" blog doesn't seem so ordinary anymore.

Finding motivation in problem-solving

## Why I'm Really Doing This But beyond the numbers, let me be honest about my deeper motivation. It's not some noble quest for knowledge or a childhood dream of becoming a programmer. It's pure frustration. As a business analyst, I see problems everywhere and work to find solutions, but when it comes to actually building something to fix these problems? I hit a wall. I'm always dependent on others to tell me what's possible and what isn't. I love automation and see so many opportunities to streamline processes, but I can't act on them. But someone's words really impacted me in my day-to-day challenges: "It's not impossible, you just haven't found a way yet." That shift in perspective changed everything for me. I'm tired of accepting limitations that might not actually exist. Learning Python is my way of taking back control. ## The Learning Journal Reality Everyone in the programming world repeats the same mantra: "Code, code, code - that's how you learn better." And they're absolutely right. But what they don't always mention is that documenting your coding journey can be just as valuable as the coding itself. When you write about what you're learning, you're forced to: - Articulate your understanding in clear terms - Identify gaps in your knowledge - Reflect on your problem-solving process - Solidify concepts by explaining them to others - Track your actual progress beyond just completed projects This isn't just a blog - it's my learning journal made public. ## Where I Am Right Now I've just completed the very beginning - variables and basic data types. Yes, I know that sounds incredibly basic to anyone reading this who's been coding for years. But for me, understanding that I can store information in variables and manipulate different types of data feels like unlocking the first piece of a much bigger puzzle. I'm literally at the starting line, and that's exactly why I want to document this journey. ## What's Coming Next I've mapped out my learning path, and honestly, looking at it feels both exciting and overwhelming: **Immediate Next Steps:** - Control flow and decision-making logic - Adding randomness and working with lists - Mastering loops and iteration - Learning to write functions - Building my first real project: a Hangman game **The Bigger Picture:** After I get through the fundamentals, I want to dive into more complex projects. I'm also curious about artificial intelligence - specifically exploring MCP servers and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). But I'm getting ahead of myself. First, I need to master the basics. ## My 2025 Goals I'm setting some concrete targets for myself: - Complete numerous mini projects to reinforce what I'm learning - Build strong Python fundamentals that I can rely on - Shift my mindset from "I need someone technical to do this" to "I can figure this out myself" - Write clean, readable code that other people (including future me) can understand The ultimate goal? By the end of 2025, I want to be autonomous in writing Python code. I want to stop being the person who has ideas but needs others to implement them. ## Why "Basic" Actually Matters Yes, what I'm learning might be basic to experienced developers. But here's the thing: - Every expert was once a beginner who struggled with these same "basic" concepts - Different perspectives help different learners - my way of explaining might click for someone when others didn't - Authenticity resonates - real struggles and genuine discoveries are more valuable than polished tutorials - Documentation creates accountability - public learning keeps me motivated and consistent ## My Unique Perspective What makes my journey worth sharing isn't that I'm special or exceptionally talented. It's that I'm genuinely documenting the learning process from my particular background: - The confusion moments when concepts don't click immediately - The breakthrough feelings when something finally makes sense - How I connect programming concepts to business analysis work - The mistakes I make and how I debug them - The connections I draw between different concepts

The ongoing journey of learning and documentation

## What This Blog Will Actually Cover Don't expect polished tutorials or expert advice. This blog isn't about teaching you Python (there are amazing resources for that already, and I follow them myself - I'm a newbie, a starter, a rookie). This blog is about sharing the real experience of learning Python: - Project reflections - What worked, what didn't, and why - Concept connections - How new ideas build on previous learning - Problem-solving approaches - My thought process through challenges - Learning strategies - What techniques help me grasp difficult topics - Honest struggles - When things don't go as planned ## For Future Me (and Maybe You) I'm writing this primarily for future me - to remember how far I've come and what strategies worked best. But if my perspective helps even one other person feel less alone in their learning journey, then joining that exclusive 0.04% was absolutely worth it. ## The Reality Check I have no idea if I'll be any good at this. I don't know if I'll love programming or just find it useful. I can't predict how long it will take me to feel confident or what obstacles I'll hit along the way. What I do know is that I'm tired of being limited by my technical skills. I'm ready to learn, I'm ready to struggle, and I'm ready to document the whole messy process. Your learning journey matters. Your perspective matters. Your documentation matters. The world doesn't need another perfect tutorial. But it might need your authentic experience of figuring things out, one concept at a time. --- *This is day one of documenting my Python journey. I have no idea where this will lead, but I'm curious to find out. If you're starting out too, maybe we can figure this out together.*

title: Starting My Python Adventure – Variables and First Steps
content:
*Posted on PyArch.dev | Beginner Python Category*

![Starting My Python Adventure – Variables and First Steps](/static/uploads/6f21f71726814f5c8f0659028d099331.png)

# Welcome to My Python Variables Journey

This is my very first entry in my **Beginner Python** journal. The projects I completed live in my `beginner-python-projects/01_variables` folder on GitHub. I am following a Python course and, right from the start, making it my own with personal touches and extra experimentation.

I have just finished my first set of Python projects focusing on **variables**, and I am amazed at how much you can accomplish with such simple concepts. Here is what I learned while working through these foundational projects.

---

## The Learning Process

Following the course structure while adding my own flair has become my preferred approach. Instead of simply copying the examples, I:
- Used my own prompts and messages that felt more natural
- Added extra validation steps that the course did not include
- Experimented with different ways to format output
- Created test scenarios with personal data

This *follow but make it mine* method helps concepts stick much faster.

---

## My Project Lineup in `01_variables`

Here is an overview of the 10 projects I built as part of this batch:

| Project Number | Filename                       | Description                                            |
| -------------- | ------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------ |
| 01             | `01_personalized_greeting.py`  | Interactive greeting using `input()` and variables      |
| 02             | `02_name_length_calculator.py` | Using `len()` to calculate name length with feedback    |
| 03             | `03_band_name_generator.py`    | Creative band name generator with randomness            |
| 04             | `04_swap_two_variables.py`     | Swapping values with Python's elegant single-line swap  |
| 05             | `05_age_statement.py`          | Simple variable usage for age statements                |
| 06             | `06_simple_addition.py`        | Adding two numbers from user input                      |
| 07             | `07_favourite_things_sentence.py` | Building sentences from favorite things             |
| 08             | `08_multi_line_print.py`       | Printing multi-line strings and formatting output       |
| 09             | `09_initials_creator.py`       | Extracting initials from first and last name            |
| 10             | `10_yes_no_questions.py`       | Asking yes/no questions and printing responses          |

---

## What I Learned

Following a course while adding personal customizations taught me:
- Input validation basics (still learning this one)
- String manipulation and formatting (enhanced with custom messages)
- The `len()` function and basic string methods
- How Python's simplicity does not mean it lacks power
- That user experience matters even in small programs

---

## For My Fellow Rookies

If you are working through variables and fundamentals, here is what I found useful:
- Don't just copy examples, personalize prompts and messages
- Test with your own data (names, favorites, etc.) to stay engaged
- Build small projects frequently to build confidence
- Experiment with formatting even when not required
- Python often has elegant shortcuts for common patterns—look for them

---

## What's Next

I will be moving into data types and more complex logic. The course introduces lists and conditionals next, which feels like a significant step. I am excited to see how much I can customize once I have more tools.

Before that, I plan to practice these variable fundamentals more to build muscle memory, especially for string formatting and input handling.

---

**Project Status:** ✅ Complete (but always room for improvement)  
**GitHub:** beginner-python-projects/01_variables  
**Difficulty Level:** Beginner  
**Time Spent:** Longer than expected (lots of experimenting)  
**Lines of Code:** Approximately 50 across multiple small projects  
**Tags:** beginner, variables, fundamentals, first-project

---

Keep coding, keep learning.  
– A Python Rookie
